s.text: Can we use UCS as a common denominator for that?
Changing the character sets in this world is not an option, as current systems run applications which can support only the character sets used by that system.
If we consider the other scripts used in Europe and the other encodings the number of different charater set codes rise to as many as 40.
The same applies to the other global information services on the network (e.g the data bases used in many information servers).

In many parts of the world it is seen as essential for the success of the global services that they should be able to recognize, store, and present textual information like personal and organizational names, represented in the character sets used by those concerned.

Some amount of profiling may be necessary for UCS use in some countries, do we need to specify that globally or we can leave it to particular region to be solved as regional matter?

Do we need to differentiate or specify how tagged data (i.e the field typ e in a data base)and how "serialized byte order" data are treated in a communication protocol or will some common specification for the tag and the type be sufficient?
Can we define a mechanism to identify the serialized byte order of a data stream?
The order of octets in the interchange of data is left to be specified by the sender and the recipient in UCS.

In many parts of the world it is seen as essential for the success of the global services that they should be able to recognize, store, and present textual information like personal and organizational names, represented in the character sets used by those concerned.

However, our criteria for this BOF should be that it helps illuminate and define the problem and advances the understanding needed to define WGs, and I think it is more likely to do that than anything else we are likely to come up with.
